posts.post_content:
Aaron\_Forsythe said : "Mark Tedin is the **one** illustrator that has been working on Magic cards more or less continually since the very first set through today." (emphasis mine)  
  
Rob Alexander might be somewhat hurt by that, Aaron. Granted, he has 54 cards less than Tedin, but as far as I can see, he did at least one card in every early set except Antiquities and in every block except Mirage, so he definitely fits that descrption too, I think.

Posted By: themlsna (1/14/2011 3:33:02 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
It's still a beast in casual play. I run a black/white deck with three LoP and a few things that can prevent the upkeep damage if necessary, like [Circle of Protection: Black](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Circle of Protection: Black). Just for grins I've also got [Samite Ministration](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Samite Ministration) with which I can gain 7 life instead of taking 7 damage for one turn. And of course some oldschool black mana acceleration.  
Now, on the rulings - I've always played it with the Circle of Protection and just paid 1 instead of sacking a creature. I guess I can only do this if I do not have any creatures?
posts.html:

Just for grins I've also got Samite Ministration with which I can gain 7 life instead of taking 7 damage for one turn. And of course some oldschool black mana acceleration.
Now, on the rulings - I've always played it with the Circle of Protection and just paid 1 instead of sacking a creature. I guess I can only do this if I do not have any creatures?

posts.post_content:
**Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #10, 10/8/10**   
   
Lord of the Pit is one of those transcendent **Magic** cards that has spawned an entire category of followers; his legion of gigantic black rares that eat your own creatures includes [Ebon Praetor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ebon Praetor), [Doomgape](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doomgape), [Devouring Strossus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Devouring Strossus), [Minion of Leshrac](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Minion of Leshrac), and the most recent update, [Xathrid Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Xathrid Demon).
  
   
Cards like Lord of the Pit—and other genre-spawning icons like [Juzám Djinn](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Juzám Djinn), [Ball Lightning](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ball Lightning), and [Masticore](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Masticore)—hit some kind of note with players (and designers) that just feels right for **Magic**, they have some unique quality that people latch on to and generally have good memories of, and thusly are worth trying to imitate time and again, even if they aren’t the most powerful cards in the game. Lord of the Pit (and [Demonic Hordes](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Demonic Hordes)) defined Demons as... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Cards like Lord of the Pit—and other genre-spawning icons like Juzám Djinn, Ball Lightning, and Masticore—hit some kind of note with players (and designers) that just feels right for Magic, they have some unique quality that people latch on to and generally have good memories of, and thusly are worth trying to imitate time and again, even if they aren’t the most powerful cards in the game. posts.post_content: After all these years, still one of the biggest fliers in the game, AND it tramples. The casting cost is just about right for what it can do, and the upkeep has been made quite manageable with all the token generators out there. Still, a 7 CMC is kind of high for competitive play.

Posted By: RafiqTheMiststalker (5/8/2010 7:10:44 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@ Aaron:  
After I have commented other replies from "Random Card Comment", I want to repeat myself here once.  
The Lord of the Pit is an icon, a symbol... that's true. But his real status was always ignored due to the fact that black is the color of creature sacrifice, but was **never ever** the color of creature hordes (production).  
  
Therefore the god of evil was combined with white protection or green token mechanic & mana acceleration. Only rarely, it was combined with Thrulls, the underwhelming [Breeding Pit](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Breeding Pit) or [Sengir Autocrat](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sengir Autocrat). The ever-present [Swords to Plowshares](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swords to Plowshares) was also a big problem.   
  
But what I really liked in your post:  
*Lord of the Pit (and Demonic Hordes) defined Demons as having a **downside** attached to an undercosted threatening body, and that blueprint has served us well over the years for making fun, flavorful cards; even though **most players** would rather not have drawbacks on their cards at a... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)*

Therefore the god of evil was combined with white protection or green token mechanic & mana acceleration. Only rarely, it was combined with Thrulls, the underwhelming Breeding Pit or Sengir Autocrat. The ever-present Swords to Plowshares was also a big problem.

Lord of the Pit (and Demonic Hordes) defined Demons as having a downside attached to an undercosted threatening body, and that blueprint has served us well over the years for making fun, flavorful cards; even though most players would rather not have drawbacks on their cards at a... (see all)
